Daily Discussion 142/782

embeds.title: Null Pointer
embeds.description:
Uncommon Attack / 1 :e_automaton: / The Automaton / Downfall

Gain 12 (15) **Block** :p_block:.
Deal 12 (15) damage.
**Encode.**
**Compile** Error - Function is **Unplayable**.

messages.content: Actual coders shudder whenever they see this card.
I'm not a coder but I see the blue screen of death so I know it's not a good thing
Overall I think the card is alright in earlygame, but other than virus I don't think there is a way to get rid of the unplayable function
a NullPointerException is what happens when you try to look for something that does not exist
like you check if variableName = 10, but variableName hasn't been set to anything yet
great early game card, and you have plenty of time to find a way to remove errors, or just take cards you don't care about losing when encoded
also you can do this
https://tenor.com/view/slay-the-spire-downfall-mod-gif-25473691
I really don't like the interaction between null pointer and <Overheat>

embeds.title: Overheat
embeds.description:
Common Attack / 2 :e_automaton: / The Automaton / Downfall

Deal 18 (24) damage.
Remove the next Compile Error you would Encode.

messages.content: If you play overheat after null pointer there's no synergy between those two cards
And overheat isn't a innate card so it happens quite often
Your only other options are dev tools and clean code (and the potion)
I wish overheat would remove compail errors both retroactively (in the already encoded cards) as well proactively (the next compail error that's encoded after it's played)
i can see that being harder to set up properly in the early game, but later you should have other good cards to play on your first shuffle that you can wait on the compile error for
also while you're waiting for that time, overheat is very respectable damage alongside null pointer, so it'll carry you through the early game anyways

Definitely a very strong early game card, most fights will be short enough that the broken function doesn't really matter. It can be rather annoying throughout the midgame and lategame though, and I agree with gangur that the methods for blocking compile errors do not interact as well as I would like them to. Having to draw them in exactly the right order to take effect makes them hard to use reliably, which makes a card like null pointer much worse, and far harder to counteract then it initially looks like. I would generally prefer to take any other strong early game card to get through that stage of the game, as the clunkiness of this card can cost you significantly during act 2, which is already the hardest part of the spire. I think it might be possible to make null pointer work, but the reward of a stronger iron wave just does not seem worth the effort IMO. You really need both runic pyramid and ways to stop compile errors before it looks reasonable. I also just don't think that automaton struggle enough with their early game to need to take a card like this. Usually your starter relic and replicate cover early game pretty well, especially if you start with red key break.
I mean <clean code> makes this card pop the hell off

embeds.title: Clean Code
embeds.description:
Rare Power / 1 :e_automaton: / The Automaton / Downfall

 (**Innate**.)
Remove the next 3 Compile Errors you would Encode.

messages.content: It's such a good combination
It's probably the best use for CC
my main issue with clean code is having 3 cards that have compile errors I actually care about removing
because a single slimed isn't really that impactful, and I feel like it usually used up all the charges of clean code
The only cards where I am really concerned about blocking the compile error from are null pointer and philosophize. I guess backtrace too, but I've not once willingly took backtrace.
I guess since clean code upgrades to innate it can be good damage
<backtrace>

and backstab only works because:
-silent doesn't start with a strong attack
-silent starts with ring of the snake
auto has <Replicate> and doesn't have ring of the snake

embeds.title: Replicate
embeds.description:
Basic Attack / 0 :e_automaton: / The Automaton / Downfall

Deal 5 (7) damage.   When Encoded, add a copy to your discard pile.
**Encode.**

messages.content: yes but it also isn't on a character with bag of prep clone, and also doesn't mess with you after you play it
exactly
also does auto need the backstab?
I would say no
Even if it didn't exhaust the function I still don't think it would be great
if you use clean code+ and backtrace combo you just spent 2 of your 5 draw on non-blocking cards... better hope of bag of prep or anchor
I prefer <overheat> as my error remover, just because I often take it anyway because it hits like a truck.

embeds.description:

messages.content: Break especially combos very well
are we talking about big damage cards or good compile error removal targets?
Compile error removal targets
You really don't want breaks downside
Break yeah, digital carnage tbh not really.
I kinda forgot about break when talking about this, but you also have to consider that it is a rare, and so is clean code. You don't often see them together.
Stacking null pointer with clean code by itself can just win you the game
It is a fair point to say that clean code isn't that good though
It's a niche effect that can be good in some circumstances
Also another thing, auto has both a status build, and if you don't go status you still have <automaton repulsor>

embeds.title: Repulsor
embeds.description:
Uncommon Power / 2 (1) :e_automaton: / The Automaton / Downfall

When you draw the first **Status** or **Curse** card each turn, **Exhaust** it and draw a card.

messages.content: so statuses as a whole are a lot less scary
Repulsor and max output is a godtier combo
which ones is max output again?
<max output>

embeds.title: Max Output
embeds.description:
Uncommon Power / 1 (0) :e_automaton: / The Automaton / Downfall

Draw 3 cards.
At the start of each turn, draw 1 additional card and **Insert** 1 Dazed.

messages.content: Insane power as auto
oh that one. Yeah, I think it's just op.
The downside can suck though
Depending on the size of the deck
The draw 3 is crazy though
play master of strategy and machine learning, and gain statuses (which auto really doesn't mind as much as other characters)
is insert draw pile or discard pile?
Thankfully dazed is the least impactful status
well the statuses cancel out the machine learning
<insert keyword>

embeds.title: Insert
embeds.description:
Keyword / Downfall

Shuffle a card into your draw pile.

messages.content: Draw
I'd still say that it balances out and might even be a little beneficial, but there's also the +3 draw
I mean you say that until you draw a hand full of dazed
well it's an on average thing
the same way that snecko eye makes every card cost 1.5
It's certainly not a card you should stack
Or maybe you do but you just need to be aware of it's downside
Stacking it can make burn out go nutty though
you'd need a 36 card draw pile to get enough dazes to fill a hand from just 1 copy of max output.
Yeah as auto that's probably not happening
Auto literally condenses their deck on the first cycle
And then you have like 10 cards
Backtrace did more when functions cost the same as the highest cost card, I think.
Yeah since it was 0 you could do some 0 cost jank with it
Now you can't anymore making the card extremely bad

The issue with clean code is that it only works the way you want after you upgrade it, and it's a rare, so you are taking it over other rares at a boss reward, or buying it at a shop for a lot of gold. Until you upgrade it, it won't block null pointer reliably enough, and once you do upgrade it, you are handicapping yourself in short hallway fights by giving yourself effectively a 4 card opening hand, and still needed to spend an energy to get it into play if you want it's effect. Innate clean code is awful in fights like reptomancer, tri slavers, and book of stabbing, basically any relatively short fight where you need good output early. I agree that clean code+ and null pointer are good together, but they are both quite bad individually, which makes it hard to find a spot where you get that combination lined up. The most natural way would be through an awkward transform giving you one of them, and then you see a reasonable opportunity to add the other.
